children.name: to prevent sb from doing sth
prevent
children.definition: to make it impossible for someone to do something that they want to do: ngăn chặn, phòng tránh

children.name: prevent somebody from doing something
examples: ▪ A leg injury may prevent Shearer from playing in tomorrow’s game.
▪ There were reports that some people had been prevented from voting in the election.

children.name: stop
children.definition: to stop someone from doing something that they want to do, especially by controlling them in an unreasonable way: ngừng lại, ngăn cản
examples: ▪ I’ve made up my mind to leave home, and you can’t stop me.

children.name: stop somebody (from) doing something
examples: ▪ My parents tried to stop me seeing Anne.
▪ The government has taken legal action to stop the BBC from broadcasting a documentary about the Secret Service.

children.name: keep
children.definition: sb from doing sth to prevent sb from doing sth, especially sth that might be harmful or upsetting: ngăn ai khỏi làm gì
examples: ▪ Staying busy kept her from thinking about her illness.
▪ It was all I could do to keep myself from hitting him.

children.name: restrain
children.definition: to prevent someone from doing something harmful or stupid, either by physically stopping them or by persuading them not to do it: kiềm chế, ngăn lại
examples: ▪ Roger stepped forward and Martin put out his arm to restrain him.

children.name: restrain yourself: tự kiềm chế
examples: ▪ She wanted to ask him all about his private life, but wisely restrained herself.

children.name: restrain somebody from doing something: ngăn ai khỏi làm gì
examples: ▪ His arm was hurting him and he had to be restrained from doing too much.

children.name: hold back
children.definition: to prevent someone or something from moving forward or making progress: ngăn lại, giữ lại

children.name: hold back somebody/something: ngăn, giữ lại ai/cái gì
examples: ▪ The police had already erected crash barriers to hold back the advancing crowds.
▪ The poor economic situation has held back investment in new technology.

children.name: hold somebody/something back: ngăn/giữ ai/cái gì lại
examples: ▪ Bill leapt to his feet to go after the girl, but the others held him back.
▪ She always felt that being a woman had held her back in her career.

children.name: get in the way of U
children.definition: get in the way of  to make someone too busy to do something else, especially something they should do: cản đường
examples: ▪ Don’t let your social life get in the way of your education.

children.name: discourage
children.definition: to make it less likely that someone will do something, for example by showing them that it may have a bad or unwelcome result: can ngăn
examples: ▪ Higher taxes are likely to discourage investment.
▪ It is a well known fact that a negative working environment discourages creativity.

children.name: discourage somebody from doing something: can ngăn ai khỏi làm gì
examples: ▪ Higher cigarette prices do not seem to discourage people from smoking.

children.name: a problem that prevents you from achieving sth
obstacle
children.definition: a problem that makes it difficult but not impossible for you to achieve what you want to achieve: cản trở
examples: The lack of money is a serious obstacle that could prevent the project from succeeding
obstacle to: sự cản trở đối với
▪ The greatest obstacle to economic progress has been mass unemployment.
overcome an obstacledeal with it successfully
▪ She had to overcome a lot of obstacles to finally make it to drama college.

children.name: bar
children.definition: a  to something  something that prevents someone from achieving what they want: là một chướng ngại với cái gì
examples: ▪ His disability was no bar to his entry into the profession.
▪ Differences in religious beliefs are not necessarily a bar to a good relationship.

children.name: limiting
children.definition: preventing sth from improving, developing, growing etc: hạn chế, kìm hãm
examples: ▪ I found the lack of available reference books very limiting.
▪ There is a lot of research that still needs to be done, but money is an important limiting factor.

children.name: hamper
children.definition: to make it very difficult for an activity or plan to continue successfully: ngăn trở
examples: ▪ Search efforts were hampered by strong winds and fifteen foot waves.
▪ The police’s work is hampered by people who file false complaints.
▪ Health care costs are severely hampering the nation’s small businesses.

children.name: hinder
children.definition: to cause problems and therefore delay the development or progress of something: cản trở
examples: ▪ Higher interest rates could hinder economic growth.
▪ Society’s attitudes about women hinder any real progress toward equality.
▪ Heavy rains had hindered the expedition’s progress through the north-west of the country.

children.name: impede
children.definition: to make progress or the development of something slower or more difficult: cản trở
examples: Progress has been impeded by a number of economic factors.
In fact, the use of these drugs may even impede the patient’s recovery.
Storms at seaimpededourprogress.

children.name: prevent
children.definition: /stop B1 to make sure that something will not happen or cannot happen, especially something bad.Preventis more formal thanstop: ngừng lại, ngăn cản, phòng ngừa
examples: ▪ Many people now believe that a good diet can help to prevent cancer.
▪ The new laws are designed to stop discrimination in the workplace.
prevent/stop something (from) happening
▪ A special valve prevents the waste gases from escaping
.▪ Stretch the rope out to stop it getting twisted and tangled up.
prevention[U] B2 when something bad is stopped from happening
prevention of
How does a healthy diet help in the prevention of heart attacks?
Educating new drivers is important for theprevention of accidents.
crime/accident/fire etc prevention
Effective crime prevention must be our main goal.
a fire prevention officer
The police are very happy to talk to local groups about crime prevention.
You know what they say,prevention is better than cure(= it is better to stop something bad from happening than to remove the problem once it has happened ).

children.name: avoid
children.definition: to do something to prevent something bad that may happen: tránh
examples: ▪ The company is anxious to avoid an expensive court case.
▪ We take every precaution to avoid accidents.

children.name: avoid something at all costsdo everything possible to avoid something happening
examples: ▪ Civilian casualties must be avoided at all costs.

children.name: avert
children.definition: to do something toprevent something bad that will happen very soon if you do not do anything: ngăn ngừa, ngăn chặn, đẩy lui

children.name: ▪ It may already be too late to avert another disaster
examples: .▪ Talks will be held today in a final attempt to avert strike action.

children.name: head off
children.definition: to do something to stop a difficult or unpleasant situation from developing, when it seems very likely to happen soon: ngăn chặn, ngừng lại

children.name: ▪ They agreed to meet government ministers in an attempt to head off a major conflict
examples: ▪ We managed to head off a financial crisis last year, but we may not be so lucky this year.

children.name: guard against
children.definition: to carefully plan and think about what you can do in order to prevent something bad from happening: ngăn ngừa cái gì một cách cẩn thận
examples: ▪ The city council is taking emergency measures to guard against flooding in the city centre.
▪ Use sunscreen on your skin to help guard against skin cancer.

children.name: to prevent sb from going swh
be in the way U
children.definition: be in the way if someone or something is in the way, they are in a position that stops you from going where you want: cản đường
examples: ▪ There’s a car in the way and I can’t get out of the garage.

children.name: be in sb’s way
examples: ▪ Could you move please Sonia. You’re in my way.

children.name: block
children.definition: if objects or people block a road, entrance etc, they lie or stand right across it, so that no-one can pass through: làm trở ngại, phong tỏa
examples: ▪ A big truck had turned over on its side, and it was blocking the road.
▪ Hundreds of protesters blocked the entrance to the President’s palace.

children.name: obstruct
children.definition: to block or almost block a road, entrance etc: làm tắc nghẽn
examples: ▪ A small aircraft now obstructed the runway.
▪ The driveway was obstructed by piles of stones and gravel.

children.name: blockade
children.definition: to use military force to prevent people or goods from entering or leaving an area: phong tỏa, bao vây
examples: ▪ In June 1948 the Russians blockaded the western sectors of Berlin.
▪ A US fleet blockaded the port of Veracruz.

children.name: to prevent a plan or action from succeeding
block
children.definition: to use something such as a law or an official order to prevent someone from doing something that they have been planning to do: phong tỏa
examples: ▪ Britain has threatened to block new EU legislation on human rights.
▪ The deal was blocked by the chairman, who was unwilling to commit so much company money to a risky investment.

children.name: obstruct
children.definition: to try to prevent someone from doing something by deliberately making it much more difficult for them: làm tắc nghẽn, cản trở
examples: ▪ The House of Lords has been accused of obstructing change and preventing scientific progress.
▪ It is an offence to obstruct the police during the course of their duty.

children.name: thwart
children.definition: to prevent someone from doing something, especially something that they very much want to do because it is personally important to them: ngăn cản
examples: ▪ Harry knew now that nothing could thwart his plans.
▪ An attempt to smuggle heroin worth £30 million into the country has been thwarted by customs officials.

children.name: foil
children.definition: to prevent something bad or criminal that someone is planning to do, by being more clever than they are: ngăn cản, chặn đứng
examples: ▪ The government has foiled an attempted military coup.
▪ The burglar was foiled by a passer-by who noticed the broken window and phoned the police.

children.name: intended to prevent sth from happening
preventive
children.definition: /preventative   intended to prevent something from happening or getting worse: ngăn ngừa, phòng ngừa
examples: ▪ We should spend more money educating people about preventive medicine.

children.name: ▪ Schools must take preventative measures so that this type of tragedy never happens again
examples: .▪ Preventative action can easily be taken to avoid damp occurring in your house.

children.name: pre-emptive
children.definition: pre-emptive strike/action/attackan action that is done to harm someone before they can harm you - use this especially about official or military actions: để ngăn ngừa
examples: ▪ The US says it is prepared to launch a pre-emptive strike with nuclear weapons if it is threatened.

children.name: preventable
children.definition: something bad that ispreventable, can be prevented: có thể ngăn ngừa

children.name: ▪ Whooping cough and measles are both preventable diseases
examples: .▪ Many of these deaths each year are preventable.

children.name: avoidable
children.definition: difficulties or problems that areavoidablecan be prevented, and therefore you should not have to deal with them: có thể tránh khỏi
examples: ▪ Running out of gas is annoying and easily avoidable.
▪ Too many children are still injured in avoidable accidents.

children.name: to stop yourself from having or showing a feeling
stifle
children.definition: dập tắt

children.name: stifle a yawn/a smile/laughter etc
examples: to try to stop yourself showing that you are tired, amused etc especially because you do not want to seem rude:
▪ She stifled a yawn as the boss read out the sales figures.
▪ Maria looked away and stifled a giggle.

children.name: hold back
children.definition: to try hard to stop yourself laughing, crying, or showing anger: kìm nén
examples: hold back something: kìm nén cái gì
▪ Jack held back his tears and pretended not to be disappointed
.▪ Sarah held back a sob of relief.
hold something back: kìm nén cái gì
▪ I wanted to laugh, but I managed to hold it back.
▪ She struggled to hold her feelings back.

children.name: suppress
children.definition: to make a strong effort to stop yourself from showing feelings of anger, sadness etc: kìm nén
examples: ▪ I suppressed an urge to laugh.
▪ He looked at me, waiting with suppressed anger.
▪ It’s not good to suppress your feelings.

children.name: overcome
children.definition: /conquer to manage to stop feeling sth that affects you very strongly, for example fear, pain etc:
examples: She managed to overcome her shyness, and stepped forward to introduce herself.
Hilton stepped into the room, fighting to conquer his feelings of disgust.

children.name: hold at bay
children.definition: hold/keepsth/sbat bay

children.name: to prevent someone or something unpleasant from harming you
examples: _Exercise can help keep fat at bay.

children.name: defy belief
children.definition: /description/explanation
examples: to be extreme or very strange and therefore impossible to believe, describe or explain

children.name: crackdown
children.definition: noun

children.name: when someone starts to deal with bad or illegal behaviour in a more severe way
examples: _There has been a series of government crackdownsonsafety in factories.

children.name: barrier
children.definition: nounPREVENTINGrào cản; vật cản trở; chướng ngại vật

children.name: anything that prevents people from being together or understanding each other
examples: _Despite thelanguagebarrier (= not speaking the same language) , they soon became good friends.
_Shyness is one of the biggest barrierstomakingfriends (= something that makes this difficult) .

children.name: keep in
children.definition: keepsbinphrasal verb

children.name: to make a child stay inside as a punishment, or to make someone stay in hospital
examples: _They kept her in overnight for observation.

children.name: keep off
children.definition: keep(sb/sth)offsthphrasal verb

children.name: to not go onto an area, or to stop someone or something going onto an area
examples: _There was a notice saying 'Keep off the grass'.

children.name: keep away
children.definition: keep(sb/sth)awayphrasal verb

children.name: to not go somewhere or near something, or to prevent someone from going somewhereor near something
examples: _Keep away from the edge of the cliff.

children.name: keep back
children.definition: keep(sth/sb)backphrasal verb

children.name: to not go near something, or to prevent someone or something from going past a particular place
examples: _Barriers were built to keep back the flood water.

children.name: keep off
children.definition: keepsthoff(sb/sth)phrasal verb

children.name: to stop something touching or harming someone or something
examples: _Put a cloth over the salad to keep the flies off.
_Wear a hat to keep the sun off (= to prevent it harming your skin) .

children.name: keep sth from sb
children.definition: keepsthfromsbphrasal verb

children.name: to not tell someone about something
examples: _He says it's alright but I think he's keeping something from me.
